hints.content: Start by understanding what a k-palindromic integer is. Recall that a palindrome reads the same forwards and backwards. For example, 121 and 1331 are palindromes.
Next, note that a k-palindromic integer must also be divisible by k. This means that any number you consider must meet both conditions: being a palindrome and divisible by k.
Consider how to generate n-digit integers. Remember that the first digit cannot be zero, as integers cannot have leading zeros.
Think about how you can rearrange the digits of a number. For a number to be rearranged into a k-palindromic integer, its digit counts must allow for a palindrome structure.

A palindrome has a specific structure: if it has an even length, all digits must appear an even number of times. If it has an odd length, only one digit can appear an odd number of times, while others must appear an even number of times.
Given that n can be up to 10, consider how many different digit combinations you can form. You may want to use combinatorial counting to determine valid digit distributions.
For the digit counts, remember that you can use digits from 0 to 9, but the leading digit must be from 1 to 9. This will affect how you count the good integers.
When checking if a number can be rearranged into a k-palindrome, focus on the frequency of each digit. You can use a frequency array or dictionary to count occurrences.
After generating possible digit combinations, filter them based on their divisibility by k. This is a crucial step to ensure the integers you count are good.
Keep in mind that the output should be the count of good integers, not the integers themselves. Make sure to maintain a running total.
Consider edge cases, such as when n = 1. You may find that the valid digits are limited to those that are directly divisible by k.
For larger n, think about how the arrangement of digits affects the possibility of forming a palindrome. You may need to explore different permutations.
You can optimize your search by using backtracking or dynamic programming to explore valid digit combinations efficiently.
Remember to check for duplicates in your digit arrangements. Use a set to track unique arrangements if necessary.
Finally, as you implement your solution, ensure that you are correctly handling the constraints of the problem, especially the leading digit rule and the divisibility condition.

questionNotes: Leading zeros are not allowed in any integer.
An integer must be counted only if its digits can be rearranged to form a k-palindromic integer.
